solution.text:
Volume of the large cube \(= 10^3 cm^3\)
Volume of the small cube \(= 5^3 cm^3\).
Therefore, number of cubes that can be cut \(= \frac {10^3}{5^3} = 8\) cubes

content.text: A cube has an edge measuring 10 cm. Find the number of cubes of edge 5 cm that can be cut off from it.

solution.text:
Area of school floor \(= 6688 m^2\)
Area of each tile = \(Base \times height = 19 \times 11 = 209 cm^2\)
Since the tiles can be perfectly broken into smaller parts, the number of tiles required is the area of the floor divided by the area of each tile. Also, remember that \(1m^2 = 10000 cm^2\)
Therefore, Number of tiles = 320000

solution.text:
Volume = Difference in volumes between outer and inner cylinder
\(=\pi \times {r_ o}^2 \times h - \pi \times {r_ i}^2 \times h\)

\(= 2\pi {r_ o}h + 2\pi {r_ i}h + 2 (\pi {r_ o}^2 - \pi {r_ i}^2)\)
\(= 3821.71 cm^2\)

content.text: Last Monday, Ram painted a rectangular wall with a cylindrical paint roller. The length of the roller is 48 cm and its diameter is 9 cm. While painting, the roller rolled over 52 times completely. What surface area did Ram paint?

solution.text:
Volume of original tube = \((\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h)\)
\(= 6260.57 cm^3\)
Now, Volume of new tube = Volume of original tube
Let the length of the new tube be x
Therefore,\(V_ {new} = (\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h) = (\pi (\frac {14}{2})^2 \times x) - (\pi (\frac {14}{2} - 6)^2 \times x)\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \frac {V_ {original}}{\pi (\frac {14}2)^2-\pi (\frac {14}2 - m)^2}\)
= 41.5 cm

content.text: A metallic tube, 83 cm long, has a thickness of 2 cm and an outer diameter of 14 cm. It is melted and made into another tube of thickness 6 cm with the same outer diameter. No material is wasted. What is the length of the new tube?

hint.text: Since no material is wasted, the volumes of both tubes are exactly equal

solution.text:
Total Curved Surface Area = \(2\pi rh = 132 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 2rh = \frac{132}{\pi} = 42 cm^2\)
Once you cut the slice, there are three faces without icing: The curved outer surface and the two rectangular inner surfaces. (Remember that the top and bottom surfaces have icing)
Also, length of Base of Slice = Radius of Cylinder and Height of Slice = Height of Cylinder
Therefore, area of the slice that has no icing
= Curved area of slice + 2 \(\times\) Rectangular surface area of slice
\(= \frac{1}{10}\)(Total Curved Surface Area) + 2 \(\times\) (Base \(\times\) Height of slice)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 132 + 2rh\)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 132 + 42\)
= 55.2 \(cm^2\)

\(= (\frac 12 \times 20 \times 80) + (\frac 12 \times 40 \times 80)\)
=\(2400 cm^2\)

solution.text:
Area of Polygon = Area of Triangle (1) + Area of Trapezium (2) + Area of Triangle (3) + Area of Triangle (4) + Area of Triangle (5)
\(\frac 12 \times a \times b + \frac 12 (b + e)(c + d) + \frac 12 \times e \times f + \frac 12 \times g \times (d+f) + \frac 12 \times (a+c) \times g\)
\(= \frac 12 \times 14 \times 15 + \frac 12 \times 32.5 \times 22 + \frac 12 \times 17.5 \times 10.5 + \frac 12 \times 14 \times 17.5 + \frac 12 \times 29 \times 14\)
\(=928.875 cm^2\)

= Area of Trapezium \(\times 2\)

\(= \frac 12 (16.5 + 22)(11) \times 2\)

Observe the shapes carefully and see if you can break them down into smaller shapes to make calculating the areas easier. Remember the following formulas:
Area of Rectangle: \(length \times breadth\)
Area of Square: \(length^2\)

solution.text:
Cross section of river area = Area of 1 + Area of 2 \(= ac \times \frac 12 (d-c) (a+b) = 133 \times 33 + \frac 12 \times 49\times(133 + 103)\)
\(= 10171 m^2\)
Rate of flow = 4 km/hr = 4000 m/hr
Volume of water flow = Area of cross section \(\times\) Rate of flow
\(= 10171 \times 4000 = 40684000 m^3/hr\)
= 40684 megalitre/hr
One week = 7 days =\( 24 \times 7\) hours = 168 hours
Therefore, volume of water flowing into the sea in one week \(= 168 \times 40684\)
= 6834912 megalitres

content.text: The Vashishti river flows into the Arabian Sea. The cross-section of the river can be approximated as the shape shown in the diagram below. You measure the dimensions of the river and find that a = 133 m, b = 103 m, c = 33 m and d= 82 m. The river flows at a constant rate of 4 km / hr. What volume of water (in megalitres) flows into the sea over the course of a week? Note that 1 megalitre = 1000000 litres

Perimeter of cylinder = Breadth of paper
\(= 2\pi r = 12\)
Therefore, r = 1.91 cm
Volume of a cylinder \(= \pi r^2h = 252 cm^3\)

content.text: Rajiv likes to make 3D shapes from paper. Yesterday, he started with a rectangular piece of paper of length 22 cm and breadth 12 cm. He then rolled the paper into a cylinder so that the cylinder is now 22 cm long. What is the volume of the air inside the cylinder so formed?

solution.text:
Curved surface area (CSA) = \(2\pi rh\)
Total surface area = \(2\pi r (r+h) = 2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 3 \times CSA = 1848\)
Therefore, \(2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 6\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow 2\pi r^2 = 4\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 2h\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2}\)
\(CSA = \frac{1848}3 = 2\pi rh = 2\pi r(\frac {r}{2}) = \pi r^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area of Base = \(\pi r^2 = \frac{1848}3\)
\(\Rightarrow r^2 = \frac {1848\times 7}{3\times 22}\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 14 cm\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2} = 7 cm\)
Therefore, volume \(= \pi r^2h = 4312 cm^3\)

content.text: A solid cylinder has total surface area of 1848 square centimetres. Its curved surface area is one-third of its total surface area. Find the volume of the cylinder

solution.text:
Given the volume of the pipe = V = 6138 \(cm^3\)
The volume of a cylindrical pipe = \(\pi{r_ o}^2h - \pi{r_ i}^2h\)
Let the thickness of the pipe be \(x\)
\(\Rightarrow V = \pi (12)^2 \times 31 - \pi (12-x)^2 \times 31\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac {V}{31\pi}=12^2 - (12-x)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow (12-x)^2 = 144 - \frac{V}{31\pi}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 12 - 9\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 3\)
Therefore, the thickness of the pipe is 3 cm

content.text: The volume of a metallic cylinder pipe is 6138 cubic centimetres. Its length is 31 cm and its external radius is 12 cm. Find its thickness

solution.text:
If the height is doubled :
V \(= \pi r^2\times h\)
\({V_ {new}} = \pi r^2 \times(2h) = 2\pi r^2 \times h = 2V\)
Therefore, the volume will double

content.text: If the height is doubled:

solution.text:
If the radius is doubled :
V \(= \pi r^2h\)
\({V_ {new}} = \pi (2r)^2h = 4\pi r^2h = 4V\)
Therefore, the volume will quadruple

content.text: If the radius is doubled:

solution.text:
If the radius is halved :
V \(= \pi r^2h\)
\(V_ {new} = \pi (\frac r2)^2h = \frac V4\)
Therefore, the volume will quarter

content.text: If the radius is halved:
A cylinder has a radius r, a height h and a volume V

solution.text:
Volume of cylinder \(= \pi r^2 \times h = \pi \times 16^2 \times 40 = 32182.86 cm^3\)
Volume of new cuboid = \(lbh\) = Volume of cylinder
Therefore, \(lbh = 32182.86 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow 32 \times 17 \times h = 32182.86 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {32182.86}{32 \times 17} = 59.16\)
The new cuboid is 59.16 cm tall

content.text: A metal cylinder of height 40 cm and radius 16 cm is melted and reshaped into a cuboid of length 32 cm and breadth 17 cm. No metal was wasted during this process. How tall is the new cuboid?

hint.text: If no metal is wasted, both objects will have the same volume.

solution.text:
Given the area \(= \frac 12 \times Width \times\) (Sum of parallel sides)
\(= \frac 12 \times 23 \times (17 +\) River Side Length\()\)
Therefore River Side Length = \(\frac{885.5}{11.5} - 17\)
\(= 60 m\)

content.text: Hussain bought a plot of agricultural land which is in the shape of a trapezium (see below). The area of the land is \(885.5 m^2\), the side parallel to the road is 17 metres and the width of the field is 23 metres. How long is the side parallel to the river?

hint.text: The area of a trapezium is \(\frac 12 \times Height \times\) (Sum of parallel sides)

solution.text:
Volume of the brick wall \(= 23 m \times 4 m \times 0.5 m = 46 m^3\)
Volume of one brick \(= 20 cm \times 10 cm \times 5 cm = 1000 cm^3\)
\(1 m^3 = 1000000 cm^3\)
Therefore, number of bricks required \(= 46 \times \frac{1000000}{1000}\)
\(= 46000\)

\(= \pi (18)^2 \times 39 - \pi(15)^2 \times 39\)
= 12134.57\( cm^3\)
\(Mass = Volume \times Density\)

= 104357.31 g

Therefore, outer surface area = 58.8 - 19.6 = 39.2 \(cm^2\)

Therefore, total cost of painting the object = \(39.2 \times 18\)
= Rs. 705.6

content.text: The dimensions of a cuboid are in the ratio of 6:5:2 (l:b:h). If the total surface area is 1664 \(m^2\). What is the length of the cuboid?
What is the Breadth of the cuboid?

solution.text:
Let length:breadth:height = 6x:5x:2x
Therefore, Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2(6 \times 5x^2 + 5 \times 2x^2 + 2 \times 6x^2)\)
= \(2(52)x^2\)
= \(104x^2\)
Given that surface area is \(1664 m^2\)
Therefore, \(1664 m^2 = 104 x^2\)
\(\Rightarrow x^2 = \frac{1664}{104}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \sqrt{16}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) x = 4 metres

content.text: What is the Height of the cuboid?

hint.text: Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2 (lb + bh + lh)\)

solution.text:
Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims
\(= 2\pi {r_ o}h + 2\pi {r_ i}h + 2(\pi {r_ o}^2 - \pi {r_ i}^2)\)
\(= 2\pi \times \frac{20}2 \times 6 + 2 \pi \times \frac{9}2 \times 6 + 2\pi({\frac{20}2}^2 - {\frac{9}2}^2)\)
= 1048.14\(cm^2\)
Therefore, cost of painting the pipe \(= 1048.14 \times 0.2\)
= Rs. 209.63

content.text: A cylindrical pipe has an outer diameter of 20 cm and an inner diameter of 9 cm. Its length is 6 cm. It needs to be painted on its outer and inner surfaces, as well as the rims. The cost of painting the pipe is Rs. 0.2 per \(cm^2\). What is the total cost of painting the pipe?
